title: Integrate structural pre-check into Challenger validation pipeline
description:
## Context

Tickets war_rig-ylbu and war_rig-v8pf provide the building blocks: Citadel context loading and structural comparison logic. This ticket wires them into the ChallengerWorker's existing validation flow so that the structural pre-check runs BEFORE the LLM-based ChallengerAgent.ainvoke() call, and its results merge with the LLM output.

## Requirements

1. Modify _process_ticket() in ChallengerWorker (war_rig/workers/challenger_pool.py, line 449). After _load_documentation_state() succeeds (line 498) and before calling _validate_documentation() (line 513), add a structural pre-check step:
   - Resolve the source file path from state or ticket metadata (state has file_name, metadata has file_path)
   - Call _get_citadel_context(file_path) to load structural facts
   - If citadel_context is not None, call _run_structural_precheck(citadel_context, state["template"], ticket.file_name)
   - Store the structural issues list for later merging

2. Modify _validate_documentation() (line 777) to accept an optional parameter structural_issues: list[ChallengerQuestion] = None. Inside the method:
   - After ChallengerAgent.ainvoke() returns (line 824), merge structural_issues into the output:
     - Convert structural ChallengerQuestion objects to the same dict format used by blocking_questions (lines 835-846): {question_id, section, question_type, question, severity, evidence}
     - Prepend structural issues to the blocking_questions list (structural issues come first)
   - Deduplicate: if the LLM also raised a question about the same section + same paragraph name, prefer the structural issue (it has exact evidence from Citadel)

3. Add optional LLM-skip optimization: If structural pre-check alone finds >= 3 BLOCKING issues, skip the LLM call entirely and return a ValidationResult with is_valid=False and those blocking questions. Log a message explaining the skip (cost saving). This should be controlled by a boolean attribute (e.g., self.config or a constant SKIP_LLM_ON_STRUCTURAL_BLOCKING = True).

4. Ensure the pre-check does NOT run for discovery tickets (_process_discovery_validation at line 915 -- this path returns early before _validate_documentation is called, so no change needed there).

5. Update ValidationResult (line 91-107) if needed -- may want to add a field like structural_issues_count: int = 0 for observability.

## Acceptance Criteria

- Structural pre-check runs before LLM call in the validation pipeline
- Structural issues are prepended to LLM blocking questions
- When structural pre-check finds >= 3 BLOCKING issues, LLM call is skipped (configurable)
- When structural pre-check returns empty list, LLM validation proceeds unchanged (backwards compatible)
- Discovery ticket validation is unaffected
- Logging shows when structural pre-check ran, how many issues found, whether LLM was skipped
- The was_sampled filter logic (lines 852-883) still applies to LLM-generated questions only (not structural ones)

## Files to Modify

- war_rig/workers/challenger_pool.py:
  - _process_ticket() method (~line 449)
  - _validate_documentation() method (~line 777)
  - ValidationResult dataclass (~line 91) -- optional field addition

## Dependencies

- Depends on: war_rig-ylbu (Citadel context loading)
- Depends on: war_rig-v8pf (Structural comparison logic)

title: M2: Parser Engine - Deterministic Extraction
description: Epic for Milestone 2: Implement the deterministic pattern-based parsing engine. This includes preprocessor for handling comments, strings, and line continuations; the core extraction engine using regex patterns from specs; and scope tracking for nested code structures. COBOL and Python specs should be fully functional by end of this milestone.

title: Implement preprocessor for comment stripping
description: Create src/depgraph/parser/preprocessor.py with Preprocessor class. Implement _strip_line_comments() for // and # style, _strip_block_comments() for /* */ style, _strip_fixed_column_comments() for COBOL column 7 indicators. Preserve original line mapping for accurate source locations.

title: Implement preprocessor for string masking
description: Add _mask_strings() to Preprocessor class. Handle single/double quotes, escape characters, and Python-style triple quotes. Replace string contents with placeholders to prevent false pattern matches. Track masked string positions for restoration if needed.

title: Implement preprocessor for line continuation handling
description: Add _join_continuations() to Preprocessor class. Handle trailing continuation chars (backslash), leading continuation chars (COBOL - in column 7). Maintain line number mapping after joining. Create PreprocessedSource model with cleaned content and line_map.

title: Implement pattern-based extraction engine
description: Create src/depgraph/parser/engine.py with ParserEngine class. Implement parse_file() as main entry point. Compile and cache regex patterns from spec. Implement _extract_definitions() and _extract_references() using ExtractionPattern models. Handle capture groups, join_with, regex flags (ignore_case, multiline, dotall).

title: Implement scope tracking for nested structures
description: Create src/depgraph/parser/scope_tracker.py with ScopeTracker class. Track nested scopes using spec's ScopeSyntax patterns. Support must_be_in_scope constraints on extraction patterns. Identify which artifact contains each extraction (containing_artifact field on RawReference).

title: Implement pattern context constraints
description: Add support for must_not_follow (negative lookbehind) and must_not_precede (negative lookahead) constraints in extraction engine. These prevent false matches in ambiguous contexts (e.g., CALL 'literal' vs CALL variable).

title: Create unit tests for parser components
description: Write comprehensive unit tests for Preprocessor (comment/string/continuation handling), ParserEngine (pattern extraction), ScopeTracker (nested scopes). Test against COBOL and Python sample files. Verify line number accuracy after preprocessing.

title: Validate COBOL spec with real samples
description: Test COBOL spec against realistic COBOL samples. Verify extraction of PROGRAM-ID, paragraphs, CALL statements (literal and variable), PERFORM, EXEC SQL (SELECT/INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE), EXEC CICS (LINK/XCTL/READ/WRITE/SEND/RECEIVE MAP), COPY statements. Fix spec patterns as needed.

title: Validate Python spec with real samples
description: Test Python spec against realistic Python samples. Verify extraction of class definitions, function definitions, method definitions, import statements (import X, from X import Y), function calls, SQLAlchemy table references, execute SQL patterns. Fix spec patterns as needed.

title: Create DocumentValidator class for type-specific validation
description:
Implement DocumentValidator class in war_rig/validation/document_validator.py.

The validator should:
1. Detect file type from filename extension (reuse logic from ScribeWorker._determine_file_type)
2. Look up type-specific criteria from CRITERIA_REGISTRY
3. Check each criterion against the template content
4. Create ChromeTicket for each failed criterion
5. Return ValidationResult with pass/fail status and tickets

Key methods:
- validate_document(file_name, program_id, template, file_type=None) -> ValidationResult
- _detect_file_type(file_name, template) -> FileType
- _check_criterion(template, criterion, file_type) -> bool
- _has_meaningful_content(items: list) -> bool (avoid placeholders)
- _create_ticket(program_id, criterion) -> ChromeTicket

ValidationResult dataclass should include:
- file_name, file_type, is_valid, failed_criteria, tickets
acceptance_criteria:
- war_rig/validation/document_validator.py exists
- DocumentValidator.validate_document() implemented
- File type detection works for .cbl, .cpy, .jcl, .bms, .pli, .proc
- Criterion checking validates section content exists and is meaningful
- ChromeTickets created with IssueType.INCOMPLETE and appropriate priority
- ValidationResult includes all validation details

title: M3: Resolution - Reference Binding and Graph Assembly
description: Epic for Milestone 3: Implement the resolution layer that binds raw references to artifacts. This includes the artifact registry with multiple indices, alias resolver with transformation rules, cross-reference resolver, graph builder for assembly, and JSON exporter. By end of this milestone, basic end-to-end analysis should work.

title: Implement artifact registry with indices
description: Create src/depgraph/resolver/registry.py with ArtifactRegistry class. Implement register() to add artifacts and update indices. Create indices: by canonical name, by alias, by type. Implement lookup() returning (artifact, confidence) tuples, lookup_exact() for ID lookup, get_by_type(), get_all(), size().

title: Create basic integration test
description: Write integration test running full analysis on mixed sample repository. Verify end-to-end: discovery finds files, specs load, parsing extracts artifacts/references, resolution binds references, graph builds with statistics. Assert expected artifact counts and relationship types.

title: Implement fuzzy matching in registry
description: Add lookup_fuzzy() to ArtifactRegistry. Use normalized Levenshtein distance for similarity scoring. Support threshold parameter to filter low-confidence matches. Consider expected_type for filtering candidates. Return sorted results by confidence descending.

title: Implement alias resolver with transformations
description: Create src/depgraph/resolver/alias_resolver.py with AliasResolver class. Implement resolve() method with fallback chain: _try_exact() -> _try_alias() -> _try_transformations() -> _try_fuzzy(). Implement TRANSFORMATIONS dict with uppercase, lowercase, remove_hyphens, remove_underscores, truncate_N functions.

title: Define built-in alias rules
description: Create alias_rules.yaml or embed in code the standard alias rules: COBOL SQL to DDL tables (uppercase, remove_hyphens, truncate_8), copybook to table (remove record suffixes), JCL dataset to file (extract_last_qualifier), CICS file to VSAM. Set appropriate confidence_base values.

title: Implement cross-reference resolver

Track UnresolvedReference for failed resolutions with candidates and best_score. Support batching for later LLM disambiguation.

title: Implement graph builder for assembly

title: Implement JSON exporter

Implement analyze() as main entry point coordinating all phases: _run_discovery(), _resolve_specs(), _parse_files() (parallel), _register_artifacts(), _resolve_references(), _build_graph(). Wire up all components with proper error handling.

title: Create SkillsGenerator core class with directory structure management
description:
## Context

War Rig generates documentation in an output directory (final/programs/*.doc.json, SYSTEM_OVERVIEW.md, CALL_GRAPH.md, etc.). We need to convert this into Agent Skills format for progressive discovery.

## Requirements

1. Create `war_rig/skills/generator.py` with `SkillsGenerator` class
2. Accept input directory path (War Rig output directory)
3. Create skills output directory at sibling level (e.g., output/ -> skills-output/)
4. Support --output-dir override option
5. Create subdirectory structure:
   - system-overview/
   - call-graph/
   - datacards/ (if DATACARDS.md exists)
   - programs/<program-name>/
   - programs/<program-name>/references/

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] SkillsGenerator class initializes with input_dir path
- [ ] Validates input directory exists and contains expected files
- [ ] Creates output directory structure as specified
- [ ] Supports output_dir parameter to override default naming
- [ ] Has generate() method that orchestrates the conversion
- [ ] Uses pathlib for all path operations
- [ ] Follows existing code conventions (Google docstrings, type hints)

## Technical Notes

- Input structure: output/final/programs/*.doc.json, SYSTEM_OVERVIEW.md, CALL_GRAPH.md
- Output should be sibling directory: skills-output/ or custom via --output-dir
- Reference existing scripts like generate_call_graph.py for patterns
close_reason: Implemented SkillsGenerator class with input directory validation, output directory structure creation, and documentation file discovery methods.

title: [codewhisper] Add get_markdown_summary function to citadel SDK
description:
Add a new function to the citadel SDK that extracts the first meaningful paragraph/summary from a markdown documentation file.

## Context
The skill generator needs to extract 1-line summaries from existing documentation files to create SKILL.md index files. The citadel SDK should provide this utility since it already handles markdown parsing and file operations.

## Requirements
- Add `get_markdown_summary(file_path: Path) -> dict` to citadel SDK
- Should extract:
  - `title`: From first H1 heading
  - `summary`: First paragraph after the Purpose/Summary section (or first paragraph if no section headers)
  - `file_type`: Extracted from metadata if present (e.g., 'FileType.COBOL')
- Handle gracefully when file is missing, unreadable, or has no summary

## Technical Notes
- Located at: /home/andras/war_rig/citadel/src/citadel/sdk.py
- Follow existing patterns in the SDK (dataclasses, to_dict methods)
- Add corresponding convenience function at module level

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Function extracts title from H1 heading
- [ ] Function extracts summary from Purpose section or first paragraph
- [ ] Function handles missing/invalid files gracefully
- [ ] Unit tests cover happy path and edge cases
- [ ] Type hints and docstrings follow existing patterns
notes: Implementation complete. Added get_markdown_summary() to Citadel class and as standalone convenience function. Features: Extracts title from first H1 (ATX or Setext style); Parses YAML frontmatter between --- markers; Finds first meaningful paragraph (skips headings, code blocks, badges, images, lists); Truncates at word boundary with ellipsis; Handles missing/invalid files gracefully. 23 unit tests covering all edge cases.

## Context

The CALL_GRAPH.md contains Mermaid diagrams and tables showing program call relationships. This should be converted to a skill that helps agents understand program dependencies and find related programs.

## Requirements

1. Create `war_rig/skills/call_graph_skill.py` with `CallGraphSkillGenerator` class
2. Generate call-graph/SKILL.md from CALL_GRAPH.md
3. SKILL.md frontmatter:
   ```yaml
   ---
   name: call-graph
   description: Program call relationships and dependencies. Shows which programs call each other and external dependencies.
   metadata:
     author: war-rig
     version: "1.0"
     total_programs: <count>
     total_calls: <count>
   ---
   ```
4. SKILL.md body should include:
   - Mermaid diagram (or simplified version if too large)
   - Entry points list
   - External dependencies
   - How to use this information

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Reads and parses CALL_GRAPH.md
- [ ] Extracts statistics (programs, calls, external deps)
- [ ] Includes Mermaid diagram if under size limit
- [ ] Lists entry points with brief descriptions
- [ ] Lists external dependencies and what calls them
- [ ] Provides guidance on finding calling/called programs
- [ ] Handles missing CALL_GRAPH.md gracefully (skip or warn)

## Technical Notes

- CALL_GRAPH.md contains: Mermaid flowchart, entry points, external dependencies, statistics table
- May need to summarize large diagrams to fit token limits
- Consider splitting into SKILL.md (summary) and references/ (full diagram) if too large

title: Fix get_callers() performance: use dependency graph instead of per-paragraph discovery
description:
## Problem

`get_callers()` is called per-paragraph in a loop within `_enrich_paragraphs_with_citadel()` (scribe_pool.py:548). Each call to `get_callers()` runs a full `FileDiscovery.discover()` (citadel/src/citadel/sdk.py:1052-1053), which scans the entire source directory.

This causes N directory scans for N paragraphs - massive overhead that significantly slows down documentation generation for codebases with many paragraphs.

## Root Cause

The `get_callers()` method in Citadel SDK (sdk.py:1040-1069) performs:
1. Directory discovery to find all source files
2. Analysis of each file to find caller references

This is done from scratch on every call, even though War Rig already generates a complete dependency graph upfront.

## Solution

War Rig already generates a `dependency_graph.json` upfront via Citadel during `_generate_citadel_graph()` (ticket_engine.py:2130-2147). This graph contains all call relationships (who calls whom) and is already passed to ScribeWorkerPool via `dependency_graph_path`.

The fix should:
1. Load the dependency graph once when ScribeWorkerPool initializes (it's already passed via constructor)
2. Build a callers lookup dict from the graph edges during initialization
3. Replace the per-paragraph `get_callers()` call at scribe_pool.py:548 with a simple dict lookup

## Key Locations

- `war_rig/workers/scribe_pool.py:548` - The problematic `get_callers()` call inside `_enrich_paragraphs_with_citadel()`
- `war_rig/orchestration/ticket_engine.py:2130-2147` - `_generate_citadel_graph()` creates the dependency graph
- `war_rig/orchestration/ticket_engine.py:575-580` - dependency_graph_path is already passed to ScribeWorkerPool
- `citadel/src/citadel/sdk.py:1040-1070` - Current slow `get_callers()` implementation for reference

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Dependency graph is loaded once when ScribeWorkerPool initializes
- [ ] A callers lookup dict is built from graph edges (keyed by target file+function)
- [ ] The `get_callers()` call in `_enrich_paragraphs_with_citadel()` is replaced with dict lookup
- [ ] Existing tests pass
- [ ] Add test verifying callers lookup works correctly from cached graph

title: Root cause analysis: Why Scribe sends 35K tokens without truncation
description:
## Problem

The Scribe agent is sending ~35K tokens when it should be limiting prompts to ~15K tokens (the configured `scribe_max_prompt_tokens` default).

## Root Cause Hypothesis (Based on Investigation)

**The token limiting logic was never implemented or was removed.**

Evidence from code analysis:

### 1. Config Defines Limits but They're Unused

```python
# In config.py (lines 73-76, 191-194)
class ScribeConfig(ModelConfig):
    max_prompt_tokens: int = Field(
        default=15000,
        description="Maximum approximate tokens for the prompt (will truncate content to fit)",
    )
```

The description says 'will truncate content to fit' but **NO CODE DOES THIS**.

### 2. ScribeAgent Never Reads max_prompt_tokens

In `scribe.py`, the ScribeAgent:
- Takes a `ScribeConfig` in __init__ but only uses `config.model` and `config.temperature`
- `_build_user_prompt()` method builds the full prompt without any truncation
- Simply concatenates: file info + preprocessor JSON + full source code + copybooks + previous template + questions

### 3. Source Code Is Added Without Any Size Check

```python
# In scribe.py lines 352-360
# Source code
parts.append("## Source Code")
parts.append("\`\`\`")
lines = input_data.source_code.split("\n")
for i, line in enumerate(lines, start=1):
    parts.append(f"{i:5d} | {line}")  # ALL lines, no limit\!
parts.append("\`\`\`")
```

### 4. Chunking Logic Was Removed

Git commit `ea26209` (Jan 19, 2026) removed the Atlas chunking framework:
- Deleted war_rig/chunking/ directory
- Deleted routing logic that would have split large files
- The commit message says 'Atlas was a planned but never implemented chunking orchestration system'

## Confirmed Root Cause

**The token limiting was designed but never implemented. The config field `scribe_max_prompt_tokens` is a placeholder that is completely unused by the actual code.**

The chunking framework that would have handled large files was removed because it was 'non-functional dead code'.

## Why This Wasn't Caught Earlier

- Small COBOL files (most are under 2000 lines) work fine
- The ~35K token limit is only hit by large programs
- No automated tests verify token limits are respected

## Related Issues

- war_rig-dowu: Investigation ticket (parent)
- war_rig-ekkk: Epic for Atlas chunking embedding (still open but work was removed)

title: LangGraph Workflow Orchestration
description:
Implement the LangGraph workflow orchestrating the War Rig documentation process.

## Workflow States:
1. PREPROCESSING - Extract structural hints
2. SCRIBE_INITIAL - Scribe creates first draft
3. CHALLENGER_REVIEW - Challenger validates and questions
4. SCRIBE_RESPONSE - Scribe responds to questions
5. IMPERATOR_DECISION - Imperator decides next action
6. CHROME_PROCESSING - Handle Chrome tickets (loop back)
7. WITNESSED - Documentation approved
8. VALHALLA - Exceptional quality
9. FORCED - Max iterations reached

## State Transitions:
- PREPROCESSING -> SCRIBE_INITIAL
- SCRIBE_INITIAL -> CHALLENGER_REVIEW
- CHALLENGER_REVIEW -> SCRIBE_RESPONSE
- SCRIBE_RESPONSE -> IMPERATOR_DECISION
- IMPERATOR_DECISION -> WITNESSED | VALHALLA | CHROME_PROCESSING
- CHROME_PROCESSING -> SCRIBE_INITIAL (iteration++)
- iteration >= 3 -> FORCED (auto-approve)

## Graph State:
- source_code, file_type, preprocessor_output
- current_template, challenger_assessment
- scribe_responses, chrome_tickets
- iteration_count, final_status
- dialogue_history

## Checkpointing:
- Persist state after each node execution
- Resume capability from any checkpoint
- Failed programs logged for retry
acceptance_criteria: LangGraph workflow correctly orchestrates full documentation cycle for single program
close_reason: Full LangGraph workflow implemented with conditional edges and mock mode

war_rig:

  scribe:
    model: 'claude-sonnet-4-20250514'
    temperature: 0.3
    max_tokens: 4000
  challenger:
    model: 'claude-sonnet-4-20250514'

    model: 'claude-sonnet-4-20250514'

  max_chrome_tickets: 5

## System Configuration:
system:
  input_directory: './aws-mainframe-modernization-carddemo/app'
  output_directory: './output'
  checkpoint_frequency: 'per_program'
  preprocessing:
    extract_paragraphs: true
    extract_performs: true
    extract_calls: true
    extract_copybooks: true
    extract_sql: true
    extract_cics: true
  file_extensions:
    cobol: ['.cbl', '.cob', '.CBL', '.COB']

    jcl: ['.jcl', '.JCL']

Implement the Scribe (Documenter War Boy) agent using Claude API.

title: Split large COBOL files into per-paragraph files and link from documentation
Core paragraph splitter module: war_rig/io/paragraph_splitter.py
description:
## Context

The COBOL paragraph splitter feature needs a core module that reads paragraph line ranges from `.doc.json` files and extracts the corresponding source lines from `.cbl` files, writing each paragraph to its own file in a `.cbl.d/` subdirectory.

## Requirements

1. **Create `war_rig/io/paragraph_splitter.py`** with the following functions:

### `sanitize_filename(paragraph_name: str) -> str`
- Convert a COBOL paragraph name into a safe filename
- COBOL paragraph names may contain letters, digits, and hyphens (e.g., `1000-INITIALIZE`, `MAIN-PARA`)
- Replace any characters not valid in filenames (if encountered) with underscores
- Preserve case as-is (COBOL names are typically uppercase)

### `split_paragraphs(source_path: Path, doc_json_path: Path, output_dir: Path | None = None) -> list[Path]`
- Read the `.doc.json` file and extract the `paragraphs` array
- Each paragraph has: `paragraph_name`, `citation: [start_line, end_line]`
- Read the `.cbl` source file
- For each paragraph with a valid citation (both start and end line present and > 0):
  - Extract lines `start_line` through `end_line` (1-indexed, inclusive)
  - Write to `{output_dir}/{sanitize_filename(paragraph_name)}.cbl`
  - If `output_dir` is None, default to `{source_path}.d/` (e.g., `PROG.cbl.d/`)
- Create the output directory if it does not exist
- Return list of paths to created files
- Log a warning and skip paragraphs with missing/invalid citations
- Log a warning and skip if source file does not exist

### `split_all_in_directory(source_dir: Path, doc_dir: Path, output_base: Path | None = None) -> dict[str, list[Path]]`
- Find all `.cbl.doc.json` files in `doc_dir`
- For each, derive the source `.cbl` filename from the doc.json `header.file_name` field
- Look for the source file in `source_dir` (handle both flat and nested layouts)
- Call `split_paragraphs()` for each
- Return mapping of source filename -> list of created paragraph files
- If `output_base` is provided, write `.cbl.d/` dirs under it; otherwise write alongside source files

## Technical Notes

- The `.doc.json` paragraph structure (from `war_rig/models/templates.py:Paragraph`):
  ```json
  {
    "paragraph_name": "MAIN-PARA",
    "citation": [136, 182],
    "purpose": "...",
    "called_by": [...],
    "calls": [...]
  }
  ```
- Citation is `[start_line, end_line]` (1-indexed, inclusive)
- Some paragraphs may have `citation: [23, 23]` (single line, e.g., program entry point) -- still split these
- Dead code paragraphs (is_dead_code=true) should still be split
- Source files may use `.cbl` or `.CBL` extension -- handle case-insensitively when searching
- Use `pathlib.Path` throughout, not string concatenation

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Module exists at `war_rig/io/paragraph_splitter.py`
- [ ] `sanitize_filename()` handles standard COBOL paragraph names safely
- [ ] `split_paragraphs()` correctly extracts line ranges and writes individual files
- [ ] `split_all_in_directory()` batch-processes a directory of doc.json + source pairs
- [ ] Missing source files or bad citations produce warnings, not crashes
- [ ] Output directory structure: `PROG.cbl.d/PARA-NAME.cbl`
- [ ] Type annotations and Google-style docstrings on all public functions

## Dependencies

- None (this is foundational)

title: Markdown paragraph linker: add source links to paragraph headings
description:
## Context

After splitting COBOL paragraphs into individual files (ticket war_rig-8q73.1), the `.cbl.md` documentation files need to link each paragraph heading to its corresponding split file. This enables readers to click from the documentation directly to the extracted source code.

## Requirements

### 1. Standalone patcher function (for existing .md files)

Add to `war_rig/io/paragraph_splitter.py`:

#### `patch_markdown_links(md_path: Path, split_dir: Path, relative_link: bool = True) -> bool`
- Read the existing `.cbl.md` file
- Find all paragraph headings matching the pattern `### {paragraph_name}` under the `## Key Paragraphs` or `## Paragraphs/Procedures` section
- Also handle dead-code headings: `### ~~{paragraph_name}~~ (Dead Code)`
- For each heading, check if a matching file exists in `split_dir` (using `sanitize_filename()`)
- If the split file exists, append a source link after the heading line:
  ```markdown
  ### MAIN-PARA
  > [Source: MAIN-PARA.cbl](PROG.cbl.d/MAIN-PARA.cbl)
  ```
  For dead code:
  ```markdown
  ### ~~9999-EXIT~~ (Dead Code)
  > [Source: 9999-EXIT.cbl](PROG.cbl.d/9999-EXIT.cbl)
  ```
- The link path should be relative from the `.md` file location to the split dir
- Return True if any links were added, False otherwise
- Do NOT modify lines that already have a source link (idempotent)

#### `patch_all_markdown_in_directory(doc_dir: Path, source_dir: Path | None = None) -> int`
- Find all `.cbl.md` files in `doc_dir`
- For each, determine the corresponding `.cbl.d/` directory
  - Default: sibling of the `.cbl.md` file, named `{PROGRAM}.cbl.d/`
  - If `source_dir` provided, look there instead
- Call `patch_markdown_links()` for each
- Return count of files modified

### 2. Inline generation (for new docs during pipeline run)

#### Modify `war_rig/io/writer.py` `_template_to_markdown()` (lines 416-429)
- After generating each `### {paragraph_name}` heading, if the split file exists, add the source link line
- This requires knowing the split directory path -- add an optional `split_dir: Path | None = None` parameter to `_template_to_markdown()`
- If `split_dir` is None, skip link generation (backward compatible)

#### Similarly update `war_rig/workers/scribe_pool.py` `_generate_markdown_from_template()`
- Find the paragraph heading generation section
- Add the same source link logic
- The split_dir can be derived from the output path: `doc_path.with_suffix("").with_suffix(".cbl.d")`
  (i.e., `PROG.cbl.doc.json` -> strip `.doc.json` -> `PROG.cbl` -> append `.d` -> `PROG.cbl.d/`)

## Technical Notes

- Paragraph headings in `.cbl.md` files look like:
  ```
  ### CBPAUP0C          (line 42)
  ### MAIN-PARA         (line 45)
  ### ~~9999-EXIT~~ (Dead Code)   (line 93)
  ```
- The link format uses a blockquote (`>`) for visual distinction
- The link must be a relative path from the markdown file to the split file
- Example output structure:
  ```
  output/cbl/CBPAUP0C.cbl.md
  output/cbl/CBPAUP0C.cbl.d/MAIN-PARA.cbl
  output/cbl/CBPAUP0C.cbl.d/1000-INITIALIZE.cbl
  ```
  Link from md: `[Source: MAIN-PARA.cbl](CBPAUP0C.cbl.d/MAIN-PARA.cbl)`

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] `patch_markdown_links()` correctly inserts source links after paragraph headings
- [ ] Dead-code headings (`### ~~NAME~~ (Dead Code)`) are handled
- [ ] Function is idempotent -- running twice does not duplicate links
- [ ] `patch_all_markdown_in_directory()` batch-processes all .cbl.md files
- [ ] `_template_to_markdown()` in writer.py gains optional split_dir parameter
- [ ] `_generate_markdown_from_template()` in scribe_pool.py gains optional split_dir parameter
- [ ] Existing behavior unchanged when no split files exist

## Dependencies

- war_rig-8q73.1 (Core splitter module -- needs `sanitize_filename()`)

title: Pipeline integration: wire paragraph splitter into doc generation
description:
## Context

With the core splitter (war_rig-8q73.1) and linker (war_rig-8q73.2) modules built, they need to be wired into the documentation pipeline so splitting and linking happen automatically after doc generation.

## Requirements

### 1. Integration into `ScribePool._save_documentation_template()`

In `war_rig/workers/scribe_pool.py`, after the markdown is written (~line 2106), add a post-processing step:

```python
# After md_path.write_text(md_content, encoding="utf-8")
# Split paragraphs and link them
from war_rig.io.paragraph_splitter import split_paragraphs, patch_markdown_links

source_path = self.input_directory / file_name
doc_json_path = doc_path
split_dir = doc_path.with_suffix("").with_suffix("").parent / f"{Path(file_name).name}.d"

if source_path.exists():
    split_paragraphs(source_path, doc_json_path, output_dir=split_dir)
    patch_markdown_links(md_path, split_dir)
```

- This runs for every file after documentation is saved
- Requires access to `self.input_directory` (source files) which ScribePool already has
- The split_dir should be a sibling of the .md file: `output/cbl/PROG.cbl.d/`
- Wrap in try/except with warning log (do not fail the pipeline on splitter errors)

### 2. Integration into `DocumentationWriter.write_result()`

In `war_rig/io/writer.py`, after writing the final markdown (~line 189):

- Add paragraph splitting and linking as a post-processing step
- The writer has `self.config.output_directory` and `self.config.input_directory`
- Same pattern: split paragraphs, then patch the markdown

### 3. CLI batch mode (optional/stretch)

Add a standalone CLI command or function that can be called on an existing output directory to retroactively split and link all COBOL files:

```python
# In war_rig/io/paragraph_splitter.py or as CLI subcommand
def run_batch_split(input_dir: Path, output_dir: Path) -> None:
    """Split all COBOL paragraphs and patch markdown links."""
    results = split_all_in_directory(source_dir=input_dir, doc_dir=output_dir)
    count = patch_all_markdown_in_directory(doc_dir=output_dir)
```

This enables running the splitter against `example_output/` or any previous run.

## Technical Notes

- `ScribePool` has `self.input_directory` (Path to source files) and `self.output_directory` (Path to output)
- `DocumentationWriter` has `self.config.output_directory` and can access `self.config.input_directory`
- The `SystemConfig` model is at `war_rig/config.py` -- check if `input_directory` is available
- The splitter should run for ALL .cbl files (no size threshold)
- Both JCL and copybook files are out of scope -- COBOL programs only
- Do NOT split if the source .cbl file is unavailable (just log and continue)

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Paragraph splitting runs automatically after each scribe pool doc save
- [ ] Paragraph splitting runs automatically after `write_result()` in DocumentationWriter
- [ ] Errors in splitting/linking do not crash the pipeline (warning-level logging)
- [ ] Batch function exists for retroactive splitting of existing output directories
- [ ] Integration is gated appropriately (only runs for COBOL files, only when source available)

## Dependencies

- war_rig-8q73.1 (Core splitter module)
- war_rig-8q73.2 (Markdown linker)

title: Tests for COBOL paragraph splitter and markdown linker
description:
## Context

Comprehensive tests for the COBOL paragraph splitter and markdown linker modules (war_rig-8q73.1, war_rig-8q73.2, war_rig-8q73.3).

## Requirements

### Test file: `tests/test_io/test_paragraph_splitter.py`

#### Unit tests for `sanitize_filename()`
- Standard COBOL names: `MAIN-PARA` -> `MAIN-PARA`
- Numeric prefixed: `1000-INITIALIZE` -> `1000-INITIALIZE`
- Single word: `CBPAUP0C` -> `CBPAUP0C`
- Edge case: empty string handling
- Edge case: names with unusual characters (if any) are sanitized

#### Unit tests for `split_paragraphs()`
- **Setup**: Create a temp `.cbl` file with known content (numbered lines) and a `.doc.json` with paragraph entries pointing to known line ranges
- Happy path: paragraphs are correctly extracted by line range
- Single-line paragraph (citation `[23, 23]`)
- Missing source file: logs warning, returns empty list
- Missing/null citation: skips paragraph, processes others
- Citation beyond file length: handles gracefully
- Empty paragraphs list: returns empty list, creates no files
- Output directory is created if it does not exist
- Dead code paragraphs are still split

#### Unit tests for `patch_markdown_links()`
- Happy path: source links inserted after paragraph headings
- Dead code heading format: `### ~~NAME~~ (Dead Code)` gets correct link
- Idempotency: running twice does not duplicate links
- No matching split files: returns False, markdown unchanged
- Mixed: some paragraphs have split files, some do not
- Headings outside `## Key Paragraphs` section are NOT modified (e.g., input/output `### NAME` headings)

#### Unit tests for `split_all_in_directory()`
- Multiple doc.json files processed
- Source files with mixed case extensions (.cbl vs .CBL)
- Missing source files for some doc.json entries: those are skipped

#### Unit tests for `patch_all_markdown_in_directory()`
- Multiple .md files patched
- Returns correct count of modified files

### Integration tests

#### `test_split_and_link_roundtrip()`
- Create a realistic .cbl source file and .doc.json
- Run `split_paragraphs()` then `patch_markdown_links()`
- Verify:
  - Split files contain correct source lines
  - Markdown has working relative links
  - Links point to files that exist

#### `test_batch_split_directory()`
- Create a temp directory with multiple .cbl + .doc.json pairs
- Run `split_all_in_directory()` then `patch_all_markdown_in_directory()`
- Verify all files are processed correctly

#### `test_writer_integration()` (if pipeline integration exists)
- Verify `_template_to_markdown()` with `split_dir` parameter generates links
- Verify without `split_dir` parameter behavior is unchanged

## Technical Notes

- Use `tmp_path` pytest fixture for all file operations
- Create realistic test fixtures that mirror actual `.doc.json` structure:
  ```json
  {
    "header": {"program_id": "TESTPROG", "file_name": "TESTPROG.cbl", "file_type": "COBOL"},
    "paragraphs": [
      {"paragraph_name": "MAIN-PARA", "citation": [10, 25], "purpose": "Main logic"},
      {"paragraph_name": "1000-INIT", "citation": [26, 40], "purpose": "Init"}
    ]
  }
  ```
- Test COBOL source can be simple numbered lines (content does not need to be valid COBOL)
- Existing test patterns: see `tests/test_io/` for conventions
- Use `pytest-asyncio` if any async functions are involved (unlikely for this module)
- All tests should be independent and not rely on external files

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] All unit tests pass
- [ ] All integration tests pass
- [ ] Tests cover happy paths, edge cases, and error conditions
- [ ] No reliance on external files or network
- [ ] Tests are well-organized with clear docstrings

title: Implement get_sequence_diagrams() SDK API method for Citadel
description:
## Summary
Add a new `get_sequence_diagrams(path)` method to the Citadel SDK that generates Mermaid sequence diagrams showing the longest call chains from a dependency graph.

## Requirements
- Method signature: `get_sequence_diagrams(path: str) -> List[str]`
- Input: source directory path OR dependency graph file path
- Output: list of Mermaid sequence diagram strings
- Uses the algorithm designed in war_rig-vr6e to find longest call sequences

## Acceptance Criteria
- Method is accessible from the public Citadel SDK API
- Accepts both directory paths (analyzes source files) and graph file paths
- Returns valid Mermaid sequence diagram syntax
- Each returned string is a complete, standalone Mermaid sequence diagram
- Proper error handling for invalid paths, empty graphs, malformed inputs
- Comprehensive docstrings and type hints
- Unit tests covering normal operation and edge cases

## Technical Notes
- Depends on algorithm design (war_rig-vr6e)
- Should integrate with existing Citadel graph model
- Mermaid sequence diagram format: https://mermaid.js.org/syntax/sequenceDiagram.html

## Example Output
```
sequenceDiagram
    participant A as ModuleA
    participant B as ModuleB
    participant C as ModuleC
    A->>B: call_function_x()
    B->>C: call_function_y()
    C-->>B: return result
    B-->>A: return processed
```

title: Remove LangChain/LangGraph dependency and use llm_providers directly
description:
## Problem

codewhisper's LLM implementation is architecturally wrong. It extracts API keys from llm_providers to create LangChain/LangGraph models, rather than using llm_providers directly as designed.

### Current (Wrong) Approach in codewhisper

The `langchain_factory.py` extracts private attributes from llm_providers to create LangChain models:

```python
# langchain_factory.py - WRONG
from llm_providers import get_provider_from_env

provider = get_provider_from_env(provider_name=provider_name)

# Extracting private attrs - breaks encapsulation
if "anthropic" in provider_class_name:
    resolved_name = "anthropic"
    api_key = provider._api_key  # <-- BAD: accessing private attribute
    extra_config = {
        "default_model": provider._default_model,
        "max_tokens": provider._max_tokens,
    }

# Then creates a separate LangChain model
from langchain_anthropic import ChatAnthropic
return ChatAnthropic(api_key=api_key, model=resolved_model, ...)
```

### War_rig (Correct) Approach

War_rig uses providers directly via the `LLMProvider` protocol:

```python
# war_rig/providers/protocol.py - CORRECT pattern
from llm_providers import get_provider_from_env, Message

provider = get_provider_from_env()
messages = [Message(role="system", content="..."), Message(role="user", content="...")]
response = await provider.complete(messages)  # Uses provider directly
print(response.content)
```

### Why This Is Wrong

1. **Breaks encapsulation**: Accessing `provider._api_key`, `provider._default_model` etc.
2. **Duplicates logic**: LangChain model creation duplicates what llm_providers already does
3. **Increases dependencies**: Adds langchain-core, langchain-anthropic, langchain-openai, langgraph
4. **Maintenance burden**: Must update LangChain-specific code when providers change
5. **Inconsistency**: codewhisper behaves differently from rest of war_rig ecosystem

## Required Fix

Remove LangChain/LangGraph as dependencies and use llm_providers directly, following the established war_rig patterns.

## Files to Change

### Primary Files (must rewrite)

1. **src/codewhisper/agent/langchain_factory.py** - DELETE or completely rewrite
   - Remove all LangChain imports
   - Remove `_get_provider_info_from_llm_providers()` that extracts private attrs
   - Remove `_create_openrouter_model()`, `_create_anthropic_model()`, `_create_openai_model()`
   - If needed, create a thin wrapper that uses llm_providers directly

2. **src/codewhisper/agent/graph.py** - Major rewrite needed
   - Remove LangGraph StateGraph usage
   - Remove imports: `langgraph.graph`, `langgraph.prebuilt`
   - Remove LangChain message types: `AIMessage`, `HumanMessage`, `SystemMessage`, `ToolMessage`
   - Rewrite `CodeWhisperAgent` to use llm_providers directly
   - Rewrite the agent loop without LangGraph's StateGraph pattern
   - Implement tool calling using provider.complete() responses

3. **src/codewhisper/agent/minion.py** - Moderate rewrite
   - Remove `from langchain_core.runnables import Runnable`
   - Remove `llm.with_structured_output(ToolResultSummary)` pattern
   - Rewrite `_create_llm()` to use llm_providers
   - Implement structured output parsing manually (JSON mode or prompt engineering)

### Secondary Files (may need updates)

4. **src/codewhisper/agent/state.py** - Review for LangChain types
5. **src/codewhisper/agent/tools.py** - Review for LangChain tool decorators
6. **src/codewhisper/agent/citadel_tools.py** - Review for LangChain tool decorators
7. **src/codewhisper/agent/__init__.py** - Update exports

### pyproject.toml

Remove these dependencies:
- `langgraph>=0.2.0`
- `langchain-core>=0.3.0`
- `langchain-anthropic>=0.2.0`
- `langchain-openai>=0.2.0`

## Implementation Guidance

### Agent Loop Pattern

Instead of LangGraph's StateGraph, implement a simple ReAct-style loop:

```python
from llm_providers import get_provider_from_env, Message

class CodeWhisperAgent:
    def __init__(self, config):
        self.provider = get_provider_from_env()
        self.tools = get_all_tools()
    
    async def chat(self, user_message: str) -> str:
        messages = [
            Message(role="system", content=SYSTEM_PROMPT),
            Message(role="user", content=user_message),
        ]
        
        while True:
            response = await self.provider.complete(messages)
            
            # Parse response for tool calls (could use JSON mode or markers)
            tool_calls = self._parse_tool_calls(response.content)
            
            if not tool_calls:
                return response.content
            
            # Execute tools and add results to context
            for tool_call in tool_calls:
                result = await self._execute_tool(tool_call)
                messages.append(Message(role="assistant", content=f"Tool: {tool_call}"))
                messages.append(Message(role="user", content=f"Result: {result}"))
            
            # Continue loop for next LLM call
```

### Tool Calling

Replace LangChain's tool decorators with simple function definitions and prompt-based tool selection, or use provider-specific tool calling features through llm_providers if available.

### Structured Output

Replace `llm.with_structured_output()` with:
1. JSON mode prompting
2. Manual parsing of LLM responses
3. Pydantic model validation of parsed JSON

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] No imports from langchain_*, langgraph in codewhisper
- [ ] No LangChain/LangGraph in pyproject.toml dependencies
- [ ] All agent functionality works using llm_providers.complete() directly
- [ ] Tests pass without LangChain dependencies
- [ ] Tool execution works without LangChain tool decorators
- [ ] Minion summarization works without structured_output

- DD statements: Key DDs must document DSN, DISP, and purpose

### COBOL Programs

- Field descriptions: Business meaning, not just PIC clauses

title: LLM Provider Abstraction Layer
description:
Refactor War Rig's LLM connectivity to be provider-agnostic.

**Goals:**
1. Define a clean interface/protocol for LLM providers that doesn't depend on LangChain or OpenAI API
2. Make OpenRouter just one implementation of this interface
3. Allow alternative providers to be configured via .env settings
4. Support providers that may use completely different APIs (not just OpenAI-compatible)

**Current State:**
- LLM integration is in war_rig/agents/base.py using LangChain's BaseChatModel
- Supports OpenRouter (via ChatOpenAI) and Anthropic (via ChatAnthropic)
- Configuration is in war_rig/config.py with APIConfig and ModelConfig classes
- Provider selection based on api_provider setting in .env

**Target State:**
- Provider-agnostic LLMProvider protocol in new module (e.g., war_rig/providers/protocol.py)
- Each provider implements the protocol independently
- Factory pattern for provider instantiation
- Clean separation from LangChain internals

title: Define LLMProvider protocol/interface
description:
Create an abstract interface that any LLM provider must implement.

**Location:** war_rig/providers/protocol.py (new file)

**Interface Methods:**
- `complete(prompt: str) -> str` - Simple completion
- `chat(messages: list[Message]) -> str` - Chat completion with message history
- `chat_async(messages: list[Message]) -> str` - Async chat completion
- `get_token_count(text: str) -> int` - Token counting (optional, provider-specific)

**Supporting Types:**
- `Message` dataclass with role (system/user/assistant) and content
- `LLMResponse` dataclass with content, tokens_used, raw_response
- `ProviderConfig` base class for provider-specific configuration

**Design Principles:**
- No LangChain dependencies in the protocol
- No OpenAI API format assumptions
- Simple, minimal interface that any provider can implement
- Type hints with Protocol for duck typing support

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- [ ] Protocol defined using typing.Protocol
- [ ] Message and LLMResponse types defined
- [ ] ProviderConfig base class defined
- [ ] Documentation strings for all public interfaces
- [ ] No external dependencies in protocol module

title: Create OpenRouterProvider implementation

- Handle OpenRouter-specific headers (HTTP-Referer, X-Title)
- Support all current configuration options (base_url, site_url, site_name)

**Configuration:**

- Support for: api_key, base_url, site_url, site_name, model, temperature, max_tokens

title: Create provider factory/registry
description:
Create a factory that reads .env config and instantiates the appropriate provider.

**Location:** war_rig/providers/factory.py (new file)

**Factory Features:**
- Read LLM_PROVIDER setting from .env (default: 'openrouter')
- Registry of available provider implementations
- Lazy instantiation of providers
- Support for provider aliases (e.g., 'openai' -> OpenRouterProvider with specific config)

**Registry Design:**
```python
class ProviderRegistry:
    _providers: dict[str, type[LLMProvider]] = {}
    
    @classmethod
    def register(cls, name: str, provider_class: type[LLMProvider]) -> None: ...
    
    @classmethod
    def get(cls, name: str) -> type[LLMProvider]: ...
    
    @classmethod
    def create(cls, name: str, config: ProviderConfig) -> LLMProvider: ...
```

**Factory Function:**
```python
def get_provider(config: WarRigConfig | None = None) -> LLMProvider:
    '''Get configured provider instance from environment.'''
```

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- [ ] ProviderRegistry class with register/get/create methods
- [ ] get_provider() factory function
- [ ] Auto-registration of built-in providers (OpenRouter, Anthropic)
- [ ] Clear error messages for unknown providers
- [ ] Unit tests for factory and registry

title: Fix: Implement token limiting in Scribe agent for large files
description:
## Problem

The Scribe agent sends ~35K tokens for large files, exceeding context limits. The `scribe_max_prompt_tokens` config exists but is completely unused.

## Solution Options

### Option A: Simple Truncation (Quick Fix)

Add token estimation and truncation to `ScribeAgent._build_user_prompt()`:

```python
def _build_user_prompt(self, input_data: ScribeInput) -> str:
    # ... existing code ...
    
    # Estimate tokens and truncate source if needed
    max_tokens = self.config.max_prompt_tokens  # Use existing config!
    
    # Rough estimate: 4 chars per token for code
    source_lines = input_data.source_code.split("\n")
    estimated_tokens = len(input_data.source_code) // 4
    
    if estimated_tokens > max_tokens * 0.7:  # Leave room for other content
        # Truncate from middle, keeping start and end
        max_source_chars = int(max_tokens * 0.7 * 4)
        # Keep first 40% and last 20%
        keep_start = int(max_source_chars * 0.4)
        keep_end = int(max_source_chars * 0.2)
        truncated = (
            input_data.source_code[:keep_start] +
            "\n... [TRUNCATED - file too large] ...\n" +
            input_data.source_code[-keep_end:]
        )
        source_lines = truncated.split("\n")
```

**Pros**: Simple, fast to implement
**Cons**: Loses context, may produce incomplete documentation

### Option B: Semantic Chunking (Proper Fix)

Re-implement chunking based on the removed Atlas framework:

1. **Detect large files** in ScribeWorkerPool before calling ScribeAgent
2. **Split by COBOL divisions/sections** using preprocessor hints
3. **Process chunks separately** with focused prompts
4. **Merge documentation** from chunks into unified template

**Pros**: Preserves all context, better documentation quality
**Cons**: Complex, requires restoring chunking infrastructure

### Option C: Hybrid Approach (Recommended)

1. **Immediate**: Implement Option A as a stopgap
2. **Follow-up**: Implement proper chunking for COBOL files

## Implementation Plan for Option A (Stopgap)

### Changes Required

1. **scribe.py** - Modify `_build_user_prompt()`:
   - Add token estimation
   - Truncate source code if over limit
   - Log warning when truncation occurs

2. **scribe.py** - Add truncation helper method:
   - `_truncate_source_code(source: str, max_chars: int) -> str`
   - Keep paragraph headers visible
   - Add truncation markers

3. **Unit tests** - Add tests for:
   - Normal files (no truncation)
   - Large files (truncation occurs)
   - Token estimation accuracy

### Files to Modify

- `/home/andras/war_rig/war_rig/agents/scribe.py`
- `/home/andras/war_rig/tests/test_agents/test_scribe.py`

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Large files (>15K estimated tokens) are truncated before sending to LLM
- [ ] Warning is logged when truncation occurs
- [ ] Truncation preserves file structure (keeps important markers)
- [ ] Config field `scribe_max_prompt_tokens` is actually used
- [ ] Unit tests cover truncation logic
- [ ] No regression in normal file processing

## Future Work

Consider re-implementing proper chunking after this fix is in place:
- war_rig-ekkk: Epic for Atlas chunking (still open)
- May need new approach since Atlas was 'never implemented'

title: Investigate existing large file handling logic in Scribe agent
description:
## Problem

The Scribe agent is sending ~35K tokens to the LLM API, which exceeds context length limits for some models.

The user mentioned there's 'recursive logic for large files (perhaps just for COBOL)' that should handle this, but it's not working correctly.

## Investigation Goals

1. **Find the existing logic**: Search for any chunking, splitting, or recursive processing logic that was designed to handle large files
2. **Understand the architecture**: Document how the logic was supposed to work
3. **Identify the scope**: Determine if it was COBOL-only or all file types

## Key Files to Examine

- `/home/andras/war_rig/war_rig/agents/scribe.py` - The Scribe agent (does NOT currently implement any token limiting)
- `/home/andras/war_rig/war_rig/config.py` - Has `scribe_max_prompt_tokens` (default 15000) and `max_prompt_tokens` fields but they don't seem to be used
- `/home/andras/war_rig/war_rig/workers/scribe_pool.py` - Worker pool that processes tickets
- `/home/andras/war_rig/war_rig/orchestration/ticket_engine.py` - Orchestration logic

## Initial Findings

1. **Config has token limit fields**: `scribe_max_prompt_tokens` (default 15000) exists in config but is NOT used by ScribeAgent
2. **Chunking code was removed**: Git commit ea26209 (Jan 19, 2026) titled 'Remove dead Atlas chunking code' deleted:
   - war_rig/chunking/ directory (COBOLSplitter, LineBasedSplitter)
   - war_rig/adapters/ directory 
   - Atlas-related config fields
   - Routing logic in ticket_engine.py
3. **README still references chunking**: README.md shows a chunking/ directory that no longer exists
4. **beads has open chunking tasks**: The beads system has open issues related to 'Embed Atlas Chunking Framework into War Rig' (war_rig-ekkk)

## Tasks

- [ ] Examine git history for the removed chunking logic
- [ ] Review what the Atlas integration was supposed to do
- [ ] Check if there's any alternative token limiting in the current code
- [ ] Document the gap between config (has token limits) and implementation (doesn't use them)

title: Add DOCX/Office file exclusions to Citadel file discovery
description:
## Context

Citadel file discovery (`citadel/src/citadel/discovery/file_walker.py`) excludes certain file types from processing via the `DEFAULT_EXCLUDES` list. Microsoft Office files (Word, Excel, PowerPoint) and PDF files should be excluded since they are binary/document files, not source code.

## Requirements

Add exclusion patterns for the following extensions:
- `.docx`, `.doc` (Word documents)
- `.xlsx`, `.xls` (Excel spreadsheets)
- `.pptx`, `.ppt` (PowerPoint presentations)
- `.pdf` (PDF documents)

## Files to Modify

- `/home/andras/war_rig/citadel/src/citadel/discovery/file_walker.py` (line 19-53) - Add Office file patterns to `DEFAULT_EXCLUDES` list

## Implementation Notes

Add patterns following the existing style (using `**/*.ext` glob format):
```python
"**/*.docx",
"**/*.doc",
"**/*.xlsx",
"**/*.xls",
"**/*.pptx",
"**/*.ppt",
"**/*.pdf",
```

Consider also adding uppercase variants if needed, though the existing code normalizes extensions to lowercase during comparison.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] `.docx`, `.doc`, `.xlsx`, `.xls`, `.pptx`, `.ppt`, `.pdf` files are excluded from discovery
- [ ] Exclusion works for files in any directory depth (using `**/` prefix)
- [ ] Existing exclusion patterns are preserved
- [ ] Tests pass after changes

title: Implement program skill generation from .doc.json files
description:
## Context

Each War Rig .doc.json file contains comprehensive program documentation that needs to be converted into Agent Skills format with progressive disclosure: SKILL.md (instructions) and references/REFERENCE.md (detailed data).

## Requirements

1. Create `war_rig/skills/program_skill.py` with `ProgramSkillGenerator` class
2. Parse .doc.json files and extract:
   - Summary/purpose for description field (max 1024 chars)
   - Program type, business context for SKILL.md body
   - Business rules, data flow, paragraphs for REFERENCE.md
3. Generate SKILL.md with YAML frontmatter:
   ```yaml
   ---
   name: cbact01c
   description: <extracted summary, max 1024 chars>
   metadata:
     author: war-rig
     version: "1.0"
     program_type: BATCH|ONLINE|COPYBOOK
     file_type: COBOL|JCL|COPYBOOK
   ---
   
   [Markdown body with key information]
   ```
4. Generate references/REFERENCE.md with detailed JSON data
5. Keep SKILL.md body under 500 lines (~5000 tokens)

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Parses .doc.json structure (header, purpose, inputs, outputs, etc.)
- [ ] Extracts summary for description (truncates to 1024 chars if needed)
- [ ] Generates valid YAML frontmatter
- [ ] SKILL.md body includes: purpose, key business rules, inputs/outputs summary
- [ ] REFERENCE.md contains full detailed data (paragraphs, data_flow, etc.)
- [ ] Handles missing fields gracefully
- [ ] Uses normalized skill name for directory and name field

## Technical Notes

- Input: .doc.json files from output/final/programs/ (see CBPAUP0C.cbl.doc.json for structure)
- Key fields: header.program_id, purpose.summary, purpose.program_type, business_rules, data_flow, paragraphs
- SKILL.md should be concise; detailed paragraph info goes to REFERENCE.md

title: Architecture: Design recursive directory processing with path preservation
description:
## Summary
Design the approach for recursive directory processing where files are represented by full relative paths (not just filenames) and output .json files mirror the input directory structure.

## Requirements
1. **Path Preservation**
   - Files must be identified by their full relative path from the input directory root
   - Example: `cbl/batch/CBACT04C.cbl` instead of just `CBACT04C.cbl`
   - This enables handling files with the same name in different directories

2. **Output Structure Mirroring**
   - Output .json files should mirror the input directory structure
   - Example: Input `cbl/batch/CBACT04C.cbl` -> Output `output/cbl/batch/CBACT04C.doc.json`
   - Parent directories must be created automatically

3. **Affected Components**
   - `SourceReader.discover_files()` in `/Users/andraslferenczi/war_rig/war_rig/io/reader.py`
   - `ProgramManagerAgent` in `/Users/andraslferenczi/war_rig/war_rig/agents/program_manager.py`
   - `ScribeWorkerPool` in `/Users/andraslferenczi/war_rig/war_rig/workers/scribe_pool.py`

4. **Validation Target**
   - Design must work correctly with `aws-mainframe-modernization-carddemo/samples` which has nested directories

## Deliverables
- Architecture decision document with approach
- Identify all code locations that need changes
- Define the data model changes (e.g., SourceFile, ProgramManagerTicket metadata)
- Risk assessment and backward compatibility notes
close_reason: Implemented recursive directory processing with path mirroring

title: Update ScribeWorkerPool to handle full paths correctly
description:
## Summary
Update ScribeWorkerPool and ScribeWorker to handle relative paths for both reading source files and writing output documentation.

## Current Behavior
- `_get_doc_output_path()` uses only filename: `output_dir / f"{base_name}.doc.json"`
- Source file loading assumes flat structure

## Required Changes
Location: `/Users/andraslferenczi/war_rig/war_rig/workers/scribe_pool.py`

1. **Update `_get_doc_output_path()` method**
   ```python
   def _get_doc_output_path(self, file_name: str, relative_path: str | None = None) -> Path:
       if relative_path:
           # Mirror the directory structure
           relative_dir = Path(relative_path).parent
           base_name = Path(relative_path).stem
           output_path = self.output_directory / relative_dir / f"{base_name}.doc.json"
           # Ensure parent directories exist
           output_path.parent.mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True)
           return output_path
       # Fallback for backward compatibility
       base_name = Path(file_name).stem
       return self.output_directory / f"{base_name}.doc.json"
   ```

2. **Update `_save_template()` method**
   - Accept relative_path parameter
   - Create parent directories as needed

3. **Update `_load_previous_template()` method**
   - Accept relative_path parameter
   - Look in mirrored directory structure

4. **Update ticket processing methods**
   - `_process_documentation_ticket()`
   - `_process_clarification_ticket()`
   - `_process_chrome_ticket()`
   - Extract relative_path from ticket metadata
   - Pass to save/load methods

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Output files mirror input directory structure
- [ ] Parent directories created automatically
- [ ] Previous template loading respects mirrored paths
- [ ] Backward compatible with flat structure (when relative_path not provided)
close_reason: Implemented recursive directory processing with path mirroring

title: Refactor Scribe chunking to two-phase approach
description:
## Problem
Current chunking mechanism is broken:
- Scribe hangs for 10+ minutes on large files
- LLM API errors (timeouts disguised as 401s)
- Single long-running session tries to hold all chunks in memory

## Solution: Ticket-Based Chunking

Replace monolithic chunking with ticket-driven sequential processing:

### Flow

```
Scribe 1 picks up FILE ticket:
   Citadel identifies all paragraphs
   Processes paragraphs 1-N
   Writes chunk_1.json (partial doc)
   Creates CHUNK_CONTINUATION ticket (remaining: N+1 to end)
   Completes

Scribe 2 picks up CHUNK_CONTINUATION ticket:
   Reads chunk_1.json for context
   Processes paragraphs N+1 to 2N  
   Writes chunk_2.json
   Creates next CONTINUATION or CHUNK_SYNTHESIS ticket
   Completes

...

Final Scribe picks up CHUNK_SYNTHESIS ticket:
   Reads all chunk_*.json files
   Concatenates paragraph summaries
   Generates overall PURPOSE/SUMMARY from complete picture
   Assembles final document
   Completes
```

### New Ticket Types
- `CHUNK_CONTINUATION` - Continue processing remaining paragraphs
- `CHUNK_SYNTHESIS` - Merge all chunks and generate summary

### Benefits
| Aspect | Current | Ticket-Based |
|--------|---------|--------------|
| Session length | 10+ minutes | ~1-2 min per chunk |
| Timeout risk | High | Low |
| Checkpointing | None | After each chunk |
| Failure recovery | Start over | Resume from last chunk |
| Parallelization | No | Yes (independent chunks) |
| Memory | Holds everything | One chunk at a time |

### Implementation Notes
- Chunk metadata stored in ticket (paragraph range, file path)
- chunk_N.json files stored in output/chunks/{file_name}/
- Synthesis step reads all chunks, derives summary, assembles final doc
- Token validation before each LLM call (see war_rig-vjge)

### Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Large files (4000+ lines) process without timeout
- [ ] Each chunk completes in <2 minutes
- [ ] Failure in one chunk doesn't lose previous work
- [ ] Final document quality matches single-pass processing
- [ ] New ticket types integrated with beads client

description:
## Context

The existing test file tests/test_workers/test_challenger_pool.py covers ChallengerWorker and ChallengerWorkerPool. New tests must cover the structural pre-check feature end-to-end: Citadel context loading, comparison logic, and integration into the validation pipeline. Follow the existing test patterns (pytest fixtures, MagicMock/AsyncMock, patching).

## Requirements

1. Add tests in tests/test_workers/test_challenger_pool.py (or create a new file tests/test_workers/test_structural_precheck.py if the logic was extracted to a separate module).

2. Test cases for _get_citadel_context():
   - Test successful context loading (mock Citadel SDK analyze_file/get_functions/get_includes)
   - Test graceful None return when Citadel unavailable (self._citadel is None)
   - Test graceful None return on Citadel exception

3. Test cases for _run_structural_precheck():
   a. **Missing paragraphs**: Create a citadel_context with 5 paragraphs and a template with 3 paragraphs. Assert 2 BLOCKING ChallengerQuestion objects are returned with question_type=COMPLETENESS.
   b. **No missing paragraphs**: citadel_context and template have the same paragraphs. Assert empty list returned.
   c. **Dead code exclusion**: citadel_context has 5 paragraphs, 1 is dead code. Template has 3 paragraphs. Assert only 1 issue (not 2) -- dead code paragraph is excluded.
   d. **PERFORM THRU exclusion**: Verify paragraphs in the THRU targets set are excluded from missing paragraph detection.
   e. **Missing calls**: Citadel says paragraph X performs Y and Z, template paragraph X only lists Y. Assert 1 IMPORTANT issue about missing call to Z.
   f. **Missing copybook**: Citadel includes ["CPYBOOK1", "CPYBOOK2"], template.copybooks_used has only CPYBOOK1. Assert 1 IMPORTANT issue.
   g. **Empty sections**: Template has empty inputs list and None purpose.summary. Assert BLOCKING issue for purpose, IMPORTANT for inputs.
   h. **Case insensitivity**: Citadel has "MAIN-PROCESS", template has "main-process". Assert no false positive.

4. Test cases for integration into _validate_documentation():
   a. **Structural issues prepended to LLM issues**: Mock both pre-check (returns 1 issue) and LLM (returns 1 issue). Assert final blocking_questions has 2 items, structural one first.
   b. **LLM skipped on heavy structural blocking**: Pre-check returns 3+ BLOCKING issues. Assert ChallengerAgent.ainvoke() was NOT called.
   c. **No Citadel available**: Ensure validation runs with LLM-only path when Citadel is None (backwards compatible).
   d. **Discovery tickets bypass pre-check**: Verify _process_discovery_validation does not invoke pre-check.

5. All tests must pass with: uv run pytest tests/test_workers/test_challenger_pool.py -x (or the new test file)

## Acceptance Criteria

- All test cases listed above are implemented and passing
- Tests use mocking (do not require actual Citadel or source files)
- Tests follow existing patterns in tests/test_workers/test_challenger_pool.py
- No flaky tests (all deterministic, no timing dependencies)
- ruff check passes on test files
- mypy passes on test files

## Files to Create/Modify

- tests/test_workers/test_challenger_pool.py (extend) OR tests/test_workers/test_structural_precheck.py (new)

## Dependencies

- Depends on: war_rig-ylbu, war_rig-v8pf, war_rig-09jq (all implementation tickets)

title: Modify SourceReader.discover_files() to preserve relative paths

## Summary

   ```python
   class SourceFile(BaseModel):
       path: Path  # Full absolute path (existing)
       name: str   # Filename only (existing, for backwards compat)
       relative_path: str  # NEW: Path relative to input directory
       file_type: FileType
       ...
   ```

2. **Update `discover_files()` method**
   - Calculate relative path from the search directory
   - Store in new `relative_path` field
   - Example: For file at `/input/cbl/batch/CBACT04C.cbl` with directory `/input`:

     - `name` = `CBACT04C.cbl`
     - `relative_path` = `cbl/batch/CBACT04C.cbl`

3. **Backward Compatibility**

title: Implement file locking for concurrent Scribe workers
description:
When multiple Scribe workers run simultaneously, they may try to work on the same output file, causing race conditions and data corruption.

Requirements:
1. Implement file-level locking mechanism
2. Before a worker starts processing a ticket, it must acquire a lock on the target file
3. Lock should be held until ticket is completed or abandoned
4. Other workers attempting to work on the same file should:
   - Either wait for the lock to be released
   - Or skip the ticket and move to another one
5. Locks should be automatically released on worker crash/timeout
6. Consider using file-based locks (.lock files) or in-memory locking with asyncio

Files likely involved:
- war_rig/workers/scribe_pool.py
- war_rig/workers/challenger_pool.py (may need same fix)
- Possibly a new war_rig/utils/file_lock.py module

title: Add prompt validation loop before LLM send (Imperator)
description:
## Problem
Imperator holistic review can exceed token limits when reviewing many files. Currently uses compact review as fallback, but doesn't validate actual prompt size before sending.

## Solution
Validation loop before every Imperator LLM call:

```
Build review input with N files
    
Construct full prompt (system + user + all file docs)
    
Count tokens (actual, not estimated)
    
tokens > max_prompt_tokens?
   Yes  Use tiered reduction strategy
   No   Send to LLM
```

## Tiered Reduction Strategy
1. **Tier 1**: Use FileDocumentationSummary instead of full templates
2. **Tier 2**: Reduce max_items in summaries (fewer inputs/outputs listed)
3. **Tier 3**: Batch files into groups, review in multiple passes
4. **Tier 4**: Prioritize files by importance (entry points first)

## Implementation
- Validate before holistic_review() call
- Validate before generate_system_design() call
- Clear logging of which tier being used
- Never exceed max_prompt_tokens

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] No Imperator prompt ever exceeds max_prompt_tokens
- [ ] Graceful degradation through tiers
- [ ] Quality maintained at each tier
- [ ] Logging of tier selection

title: Implement structural pre-check comparison logic
description:
## Context

This ticket implements the core comparison logic that takes Citadel structural facts and the Scribe's DocumentationTemplate and produces a list of ChallengerQuestion objects for structural gaps. This is a pure function with no side effects -- it takes data in and returns issues out.

## Requirements

1. Create a new method _run_structural_precheck(self, citadel_context: dict, template: DocumentationTemplate, file_name: str) -> list[ChallengerQuestion] on ChallengerWorker (or as a standalone function in a new module war_rig/workers/structural_precheck.py -- implementer's choice).

2. The method must perform these comparisons:

   a. **Missing paragraphs check**: Compare Citadel paragraph names (from citadel_context["paragraphs"]) against template.paragraphs (list[Paragraph], model at war_rig/models/templates.py line 436). Match by paragraph_name field (case-insensitive). For any Citadel paragraph not found in the template, generate a ChallengerQuestion with:
      - section = "paragraphs"
      - question_type = QuestionType.COMPLETENESS (from war_rig/models/tickets.py line 55)
      - severity = QuestionSeverity.BLOCKING (line 65)
      - question = descriptive text naming the missing paragraph and its line range
      - evidence = [line_start] from Citadel data
      - Exclude paragraphs marked as dead code (is_dead_code=True or in citadel_context["dead_code"]). Also exclude PERFORM THRU range endpoints.

   b. **Missing calls check**: For each paragraph present in BOTH Citadel and the template, compare Citadel outgoing calls (callout.target where callout.relationship == "performs") against template paragraph's calls field (list[str]) AND outgoing_calls field (list[FunctionCall]). If Citadel says paragraph X performs Y but the template paragraph X does not list Y in calls or outgoing_calls, generate:
      - section = "paragraphs"
      - question_type = QuestionType.COMPLETENESS
      - severity = QuestionSeverity.IMPORTANT
      - question = text naming the missing call relationship
      - evidence = [callout.line] if available

   c. **Missing copybook references check**: Compare Citadel includes (citadel_context["includes"]) against template.copybooks_used (list[CopybookReference], model at templates.py line 370). Match by copybook_name (case-insensitive). For any Citadel include not in the template, generate:
      - section = "copybooks_used"
      - question_type = QuestionType.COMPLETENESS
      - severity = QuestionSeverity.IMPORTANT

   d. **Empty critical sections check**: Check if these template sections are empty/null:
      - template.inputs (list) -- empty list
      - template.outputs (list) -- empty list
      - template.business_rules (list) -- empty list
      - template.purpose -- None or purpose.summary is None/empty
      Generate QuestionType.COMPLETENESS with severity BLOCKING for empty purpose, IMPORTANT for others.

3. Each generated ChallengerQuestion must have a unique question_id (use generate_question_id() from war_rig/models/tickets.py line 90) and iteration=1 (or accept iteration as parameter).

4. Return the list sorted by severity (BLOCKING first, then IMPORTANT).

## Acceptance Criteria

- Function correctly identifies missing paragraphs (excluding dead code and THRU targets)
- Function correctly identifies missing call relationships per-paragraph
- Function correctly identifies missing copybook references
- Function correctly identifies empty critical sections
- All returned objects are valid ChallengerQuestion instances
- Dead code paragraphs are excluded from the missing paragraphs check
- Case-insensitive matching for paragraph and copybook names

## Files to Create/Modify

- war_rig/workers/challenger_pool.py (new method) OR war_rig/workers/structural_precheck.py (new module)
- Imports from: war_rig/models/tickets.py (ChallengerQuestion, QuestionType, QuestionSeverity, generate_question_id)
- Imports from: war_rig/models/templates.py (DocumentationTemplate, Paragraph, CopybookReference)

## Dependencies

- Depends on ticket: war_rig-ylbu (Citadel context loading -- defines the citadel_context dict structure)

title: Add prompt validation loop before LLM send (Scribe)
description:
## Problem
Current approach estimates token count but doesn't validate actual prompt size before sending. Can exceed LLM limits.

## Solution
Validation loop before every LLM call:

```
Build batch with N paragraphs
    
Construct full prompt (system + user + source)
    
Count tokens (actual, not estimated)
    
tokens > max_prompt_tokens?
   Yes  Reduce N, rebuild prompt, repeat
   No   Send to LLM
```

## Implementation
- Use tiktoken or Anthropic's count_tokens for accurate count
- Binary search or decrement for batch size reduction
- Handle edge case: single paragraph exceeds limit (split by PERFORM or error)
- Return remaining paragraphs for next batch

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] No prompt ever exceeds max_prompt_tokens
- [ ] Graceful reduction when batch too large
- [ ] Clear error when single paragraph too large
- [ ] Logging of reduction events

title: Design algorithm for finding longest call sequences from dependency graphs
description:
## Summary
Design an algorithm to find the longest call sequences from dependency graphs for generating Mermaid sequence diagrams.

## Requirements
- Brute-force approach trying various entry points to find longest call chains
- Handle cycles in dependency graphs (detect and break gracefully)
- Handle multiple valid sequences of equal length
- Output: ordered list of calls forming the sequence

## Acceptance Criteria
- Algorithm correctly identifies the longest call sequence from any entry point
- Cycles are detected and handled without infinite loops
- When multiple sequences have equal length, algorithm returns all of them (or a deterministic selection)
- Output format is an ordered list suitable for Mermaid sequence diagram generation
- Algorithm complexity is documented
- Edge cases documented: empty graphs, single-node graphs, disconnected components

## Technical Notes
- This is the core algorithmic component for the Sequence Diagram SDK feature
- Output will be consumed by the SDK API implementation to generate Mermaid diagrams

title: [codewhisper] Implement system prompts and agent personality
description:
## Context
Define the system prompts and agent personality for codewhisper. The agent should be knowledgeable about mainframe systems and use skills effectively.

## Requirements
1. Create agent/prompts.py with system prompt templates

3. Include instructions for using tools effectively
4. Provide context about skills system

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Instructions for when to use list_skills vs get_skill
- [ ] Instructions for when to search code vs use skills
- [ ] Prompt encourages citing sources (skill names, file paths)
- [ ] Prompt handles "I dont know" gracefully

## System Prompt Should Include
1. Role: Mainframe documentation assistant
2. Capabilities: Skills database, code search
3. Tool usage guidelines:

   - Load skills for detailed information
   - Search code for implementation details
4. Response guidelines:

   - Be specific about program names
   - Explain mainframe concepts when relevant
